description: From Lombard artichòc, from Occitan artichaut, from Old Spanish alcarchofa, from Andalusian Arabic الْخَرْشُوف‎ (al-ḵaršūf), from Arabic الْخُرْشُوف‎ (al-ḵuršūf), definite form of خُرْشُوف‎ (ḵuršūf).

entries.meaning: A plant related to the thistle with enlarged flower heads eaten as a vegetable while immature, Cynara cardunculus var. scolymus.
A dull green colour, like that of an artichoke.
